intro: Carludovica coma-pyrrhae, commonly known as the Mexican nightshade, is a flowering plant native to Mexico. It belongs to the Solanaceae family, which includes tomatoes, peppers, and tobacco. The plant features showy, violet-blue flowers that bloom in the evening, attracting nocturnal pollinators. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and often covered in fine hairs. The fruit is a small, fleshy berry that turns red when ripe, containing several seeds.
